proposals.reasoning: Most of the table already coalesced around Alice–Bob as a solid low-drama core, and multiple people (including Grace and me) voiced mild concern about auto-locking Henry just because he usually feels good early. Starting with Alice–Bob–Frank gives us the same conservative, low-variance opener people want while deliberately avoiding overreliance on Henry’s usual meta-read. If this passes cleanly, we get a strong baseline without prematurely anchoring the game around Henry; if it fails, the pool of suspects is compact and easy to reason about for Quest 2.

votes.comment: Reasonable low-drama Q1 with me on it; no strong red flags yet and we shouldn’t over-meta Henry this early.
Solid low-info opener including me, avoids over-clearing Henry early; no strong reason to suspect Alice or Frank yet on Q1.
Safe-feeling opener that keeps both my known evil partners off the first mission; a clean pass here doesn’t hurt us and helps shape later suspicion.
Solid low-drama Q1 team that fits table consensus and avoids over-clearing Henry early; fine baseline for initial info.
All three are likely good, so a clean pass gives us a low-info baseline without exposing any evil players early.
Team excludes both known evils (to me) and fits the table’s low-drama, low-info opener everyone was leaning toward, including my earlier suggestion.
Matches my stated preference (Alice–Bob–Frank) for a low-drama opener without auto-clearing Henry; no concrete reason to distrust this trio yet.
This matches the low-drama opener I supported (Alice–Bob core with Frank instead of me) and is a reasonable baseline to start from.

discussion.content: With no info yet I’d like a low‑drama start: I’m inclined to see something like me + one of Henry/Eve (both usually read pretty naturally good early) plus one of Bob/Frank, avoiding putting both Charlie and Grace together on the first team.
I like the idea of avoiding both Charlie and Grace on Q1; something like Alice–Henry–me feels like a solid, low‑info but low‑risk opener.

Alice–Henry–Bob is fine as a super safe-feeling opener to me, especially since I get why people don’t want Charlie+Grace together early. I’d rather see a clean first mission and use that to build some structure than gamble on a spicier combo right away.
Alice–Henry–Bob is a totally reasonable opener to me, though I’d also be comfortable swapping Bob for Frank if we want to spread early info a bit.
I’m happy to sit off the first one; Alice–Henry–Bob looks like a clean, low‑variance start, and we can always bring in Frank/me on Q2 once we’ve seen how this table votes and reacts.

I’m a tiny bit hesitant to auto-lock Henry just because he usually feels good early, since that can bite us later. I’d prefer something like Alice–Bob–Frank or Alice–Bob–Diana as a cleaner way to get an early baseline.

I’m okay with the chill opener, but I slightly prefer Alice–Bob–Frank over auto-locking Henry just so we don’t lean too hard on his usual “feels good early” aura. If the table really wants Henry on, Alice–Bob–Henry is fine, but I’d like us to treat that as provisional, not a hard-clear if it passes.

I’m fine taking the shot with Alice–Bob–me as long as everyone treats a pass as just a small nudge, not a hard clear on anyone. If people are really wary of my usual early “looks good” bias, I’d rather swap me for Frank than start over‑complicating Q1.

proposals.reasoning: We get a strong core from the successful M1 team (Bob and Frank), add Charlie who has been widely suggested as a good info-gain include, and include myself so that information isn’t locked into only the same small cluster of players as last round. This setup reuses exactly two of the initial three, aligns with multiple players’ stated preferences (including Henry’s), and starts testing one of the previously untested pair (Grace/Henry) while still keeping the team relatively safe.

votes.comment: Reuses two from the clean M1 team and adds two new players for info; no strong reason yet to distrust any of them, so this is a reasonable, informative lineup.
Solid early info team: reuses 2 from the successful M1 core and adds two untested players. No strong reason yet to avoid this composition, and it helps widen our information.
Fits the broadly agreed structure (2 from M1 plus me and one new), and I’m fine testing Grace here while keeping the Bob/Frank core.
Solid reuse of two from the successful M1 plus two new players for info; nothing in the discussion makes this team look especially risky yet.

Keeps the trusted Bob/Frank core while adding only two new players, including a widely requested Charlie, so it’s a reasonable balance of safety and new info even if I’d slightly prefer being on it myself.
Keeps two from a successful M1, adds two untested for good info, and includes no obvious risk factors based on current discussion.
Solid reuse of 2 from a successful team, good info gain on Charlie and me, and I know I’m good so this is a reasonable, low-risk test.
This matches my earlier preference of keeping Bob/Frank as a core, adding Charlie, and including one of the info-starved pair without looking overly risky.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’d like to keep at least two of Alice/Bob/Frank on the next team and just add one new person, but we shouldn’t automatically clear all three as 100% good yet.

I agree we shouldn’t insta-clear the M1 team, but I’m comfortable reusing at least two of us; I’d especially like to see someone like Charlie or Diana added so we start getting info on people who haven’t been tested yet.
I like the idea of reusing two from the first mission, so something like Bob, Frank, me, plus one of Diana or Eve seems solid to get new info without throwing out what we already know.

I’m on board with reusing two from Alice/Bob/Frank, but I’d rather not put all three back on, so something like Bob, Frank, Charlie, and one of Diana/Eve feels like a good balance of safety and new info.

I’d be happy with keeping Bob and Frank as a core for now and adding two new people; something like Bob, Frank, Charlie, and me feels like a good mix of “tested” plus fresh info without over-committing to the entire first team.

I’m good with reusing two from the first mission, and I slightly prefer keeping Bob with me plus adding Charlie and Diana so we get fresh info without over-committing to anyone who hasn’t been on a team yet.
I’m fine reusing exactly two from Alice/Bob/Frank, but I’d really like at least one of me or Henry on this team so we’re not narrowing info to just the same cluster of people plus Charlie/Diana/Eve.

I’d like to keep Bob and Frank as the core for now and I slightly prefer adding Charlie plus Grace, so we get one of the “info-starved” pair (Grace/Me) involved without stacking the whole team inside the same small circle.

proposals.reasoning: This keeps the tightest overlap with the two previous clean missions while minimizing new variables: Bob and Frank are a double core from Missions 1 and 2, Alice returns from the clean Mission 1, and Charlie returns from the clean Mission 2. If this team succeeds, we’ve likely found a very strong good bloc; if it fails, we get a narrow and information-rich window of four players to re‑evaluate instead of dealing with a reshuffled mix.

votes.comment: Keeps the tightest overlap with two clean missions; if it fails, the blame window is very narrow and informative.
Both prior missions were clean and this team preserves maximum overlap (Bob/Frank core plus one from each successful mission), giving strong odds of success and very clear info if it fails.
I’m on the team and its composition is widely trusted, giving evil a key chance to influence this crucial mission.
Two clean missions with Bob/Frank core, plus Alice/Charlie each from prior successes; both Merlin candidates back this configuration, so it’s the safest, most consistent info-team right now.
This keeps the tight overlap with the two clean missions and gives a very clear info window if it ever fails.
Two clean overlaps and no new variables; if this passes we likely secure the game, and if it somehow fails we get a very tight group to reassess.
Both prior missions with these overlaps were clean; this is the most information-rich and currently safest-looking configuration without unnecessary reshuffling.
Two clean missions make this configuration look as safe and info-rich as we’re going to get; if it cracks, we have a very narrow group to re-evaluate.

discussion.content: Given two clean missions with overlap, I’m most comfortable locking in Bob and Frank again, plus me from M1, and then we can debate the fourth slot from the M2 pair (Charlie/Grace) rather than reshuffling everything.
I’m happy treating me and Frank as a locked core for now, and I lean toward re-adding Alice from the clean M1 plus Charlie from the clean M2 so we’re not reshuffling too much this early.

I like keeping the overlap tight, so Bob/Frank as core plus Alice from M1 and Charlie from M2 feels like the most information-safe team right now. We can keep Grace in reserve for later rather than reshuffling too many slots at once.

Sticking with the double-overlap of Bob/Frank plus re-adding Alice from the clean M1 makes the most sense to me, and between Charlie/Grace for the last slot I slightly prefer Charlie so we’re not juggling too many variables at once. I’d still like to hear a bit more from Grace before we completely sideline her for later missions, though.

I’m fine treating Bob/Frank as a temporary core given two clean runs, and between Alice/Grace/Charlie I slightly prefer adding Alice from M1 plus Charlie from M2 so we’re not spinning up an entirely new configuration yet. If this cracks, we’ll have a much clearer place to start re-evaluating.

I’m good with the Bob/Frank core plus Alice and Charlie here – it keeps us maximally consistent with what’s already worked without overcomplicating things on a key information mission. If this ever does crack, we’ll have a really tight window to analyze instead of a total reshuffle.

I’m okay with the Bob/Frank core plus Alice/Charlie here – both missions being clean makes that four look as safe as we’re going to get right now, and if this ever does pop we’ll have a very narrow group to re-examine instead of muddying things by reshuffling.

I’m on board with locking in Bob/Frank as core and adding Alice/Charlie here – if this team ever does flip, we get a super clean window of four to re‑evaluate instead of muddying things with a reshuffle.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 3 failed with exactly one FAIL, and the only players common to that failure and earlier teams are Bob, Frank, and Charlie. That guarantees at least one evil among {Bob, Frank, Charlie}. By excluding all three, we remove the entire guaranteed-suspicious cluster. The remaining five players are exactly {Alice, Diana, Eve, Grace, Henry}, so this team maximally avoids known risk and also aligns with the broad table consensus around a Grace + Henry core plus Eve and Diana, with me (Alice) as the fifth from outside the {Bob, Frank, Charlie} trio.

votes.comment: This fully excludes the guaranteed-suspicious cluster {Bob, Frank, Charlie} from the failed Mission 3 and matches the safest structural logic available.

Structurally best to exclude the entire {Bob, Frank, Charlie} cluster tied to the fail; even though I know I’m good, from the table’s perspective this 5 maximally avoids the suspicious group and Mission 4 needs two fails, so a single hidden evil here can’t lose it.
This team fully avoids the guaranteed-suspicious Bob/Frank/Charlie cluster from the failed mission, and aligns with the Grace+Henry core the table’s converged on.
Best logical team: fully excludes guaranteed-suspicious {Bob, Frank, Charlie} cluster and aligns with Henry+Grace core I trust more than Frank, who pushed against this structure.
Team includes two evils (me and Henry), giving us control to fail this critical mission.
This stacks both Henry and Eve, which feels too risky when we can build around Grace plus more of the proven earlier cores instead.
This team fully excludes the main suspicious cluster {Bob, Frank, Charlie} from the failed mission while using the only possible remaining 5; it’s the structurally safest option available.
This keeps all three of Bob/Frank/Charlie off the team after the single-fail mission, which feels like the safest composition right now.

discussion.content: Given I was on the failed team, I know the bad card had to come from Bob, Frank, or Charlie, so for this one I’d really like a lineup mostly from outside that group—something like me, Grace, Henry, Eve, plus just one of those three at most.
I’m on board with limiting it to at most one of {me, Frank, Charlie}, and if we do that I’d most like to see Grace and Henry locked in, with Eve as a strong candidate too.

I like the idea of a core of Grace and Henry, and I’d be happy adding Eve there too, with just one of {Bob, Frank, Charlie} to minimize risk from the last team. Personally I’d slightly lean Frank over Bob from that group based on Mission 2 being clean with him.

I really like locking in Grace and Henry, and I’d be happiest with a team like Grace, Henry, Eve, me, plus just one of {Bob, Frank, Charlie}. Given the single fail, I’d prefer we don’t double-dip from that trio at all, and I slightly lean Bob/Charlie over Frank from there despite Mission 2 being clean.

I’m on board with a Grace + Henry core, and I’d really like to see this team mostly outside the last mission’s {Bob, Frank, Charlie} trio—something like Grace, Henry, me, Diana, plus at most one of them feels safest to me.

Given Missions 1 and 2 were both clean with variations of {Alice, Bob, Charlie, Grace, me}, I’d rather we anchor around Grace plus two from that group and not auto-lock Henry off the back of leading the failed team. I’m okay with adding one of Henry/Eve for coverage, but I’d really prefer we don’t stack both of them here.

I’m very happy locking in a Grace + Henry core, and I’d most like to see a team of me, Henry, Eve, Diana, plus just one of the last mission’s trio—leaning Alice there and avoiding the Bob/Frank double‑up that’s been on every team so far.
I’m very comfortable with a core of Grace + me + Eve + Diana, and I’d lean adding Alice as the fifth so we minimize overlap with the Bob/Frank/Charlie group from the failed mission.

proposals.reasoning: We need to minimize overlap with the two failing missions while anchoring around the strongest information we have. Missions 1 and 2 both succeeded with 0 fails and shared Bob and Frank; they were also both on Mission 3 (the single-fail), making it much more likely that the spy on Mission 3 was Alice or Charlie rather than both Bob and Frank suddenly choosing to fail after two clean missions. That makes Bob and Frank the best anchors. Alice is the only player on both failed missions (3 and 4), which makes her the single most suspicious player; she should be excluded. Mission 4’s fail came from among {Alice, Diana, Eve, Grace, Henry}. If Alice is evil, then Diana, Eve, Grace, and Henry can all still be good; even if Alice is actually good, at most one of Diana/Eve/Grace/Henry is evil because only one fail appeared. The broad table consensus (from Charlie, Diana, Eve, Henry) converged on a core of Bob/Frank/Diana/Henry as the safest four. Between the remaining candidates for the fifth slot (Eve vs. Grace vs. Charlie vs. re-adding Alice), Eve is least tied to previous fails: Charlie is tied to the Mission 3 fail, Grace to the Mission 4 fail and to the Mission 2 spy pool, and Alice is tied to both fails. Therefore, the team Bob, Frank, Diana, Henry, and Eve uses the best-info core, removes the double-overlap Alice, avoids Charlie/Grace who are each connected to one of the fails, and aligns with the majority’s preferred structure for the final mission.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, so the logic of excluding me as the double-overlap is wrong. From my perspective at least one spy is among {B,F,C} and at least one among {D,E,G,H}, and this team takes two from the first set (B,F) and three from the second (D,E,H), which feels too likely to contain a spy.
If Bob and Frank are good, only 1 of 16 consistent spy combinations makes D/E/H all good; in the other 15, at least one of Diana/Eve/Henry is evil, so this team is very likely contaminated.
Two of my evil teammates are on this team and likely can secure the mission fail for a win.
Core aligns with both early clean missions and my Merlin read on Henry; excludes Alice as double-overlap on both fails and avoids Charlie/Grace who’re each tied to a fail.
This best fits the low-overlap logic around the two failing missions while keeping Alice, the double-overlap, off the team.
Too many players from the last failed mission’s pool; I’d rather base the final team more heavily on the fully clean Missions 1 and 2 without pulling in both Henry and Eve together.
I know I’m good, and Eve’s only mission appearance was on the failing Mission 4, so from my perspective a safer version of this structure would swap Eve for me.
Two evils (including me and Eve) are on this team with a strong ‘safe core’ narrative backing it, giving us a great chance to secure the final fail.

proposals.reasoning: This team follows the emerging consensus core of Bob, Frank, Diana, and Henry, who have broad table support as the safest combination given the mission history. For the fifth slot, adding Eve is preferred because it keeps Alice (the only player overlapping both failed missions) off the team, and avoids reintroducing Charlie or Grace, who are each tied to one of the failed missions. This lineup matches what multiple players (including me earlier) have called the 'cleanest-looking' five and best fits the collective logic expressed in the discussion.

votes.comment: Given I know I’m good, there’s no way all five on this team can be good—at least one must be evil based on the mission overlaps and the total of 3 evils, so this lineup can’t be safe for the final quest.

This is the cleanest team: it keeps Alice (double overlap on both fails) and both Charlie/Grace (each tied to a fail) off, while building around the broadly agreed Bob/Frank/Diana/Henry core with Eve as the least-tainted fifth.
This matches the Bob/Frank/Henry/Diana core plus Eve that I already called the cleanest-looking team and keeps Alice, Grace, and me (all tied to fails) off the mission.
As Percival I know exactly one of Frank/Henry is evil (Morgana), so putting both of them on the final mission guarantees at least one evil on a must-succeed team.

I’m still not comfortable calling this core ‘safe’ when Henry’s only mission appearance was on a fail; I’d rather re-evaluate and consider at least one of Alice/Grace/Charlie instead of locking this in.

I’m still not comfortable with Henry as part of a ‘safe core,’ and adding Eve alongside him feels too close to the Mission 4 fail pattern. I’d rather build around the players from the two clean teams instead.

This matches the broad consensus core (Bob/Frank/Diana/Henry) plus Eve, keeps Alice (double-overlap on both fails) off, and avoids reusing Charlie/Grace who are each tied to a single fail; most likely to reflect hidden good info among the supporters.
Matches the Bob/Frank/Diana/Henry core I trust most, and I still slightly prefer Eve as the fifth over re-adding anyone tied more heavily to past fails.

proposals.reasoning: I’m anchoring the team around the broadest consensus core and minimizing overlap with the two failing missions. Bob and Frank were on the two clean missions together and only picked up a single fail when paired with Alice and Charlie on Mission 3, which still makes them the most structurally trusted pair. Henry and I (Diana) were only present on the single-fail Mission 4, but are strongly supported by multiple players as part of the safest core; if there’s exactly one spy from that mission among us, including both of us still keeps the odds favorable when paired with the more trusted Bob/Frank block. For the fifth slot, I’m choosing Eve over Alice/Charlie/Grace because: (1) Alice is the only double-overlap between both failing teams, which is too big a red flag for this final mission; (2) Charlie is tightly tied to the Mission 3 fail; and (3) Grace is tightly tied to the Mission 4 fail. Eve’s only appearance was on the single-fail Mission 4 and she avoids the double-fail overlap and the earlier fail association from Mission 3. This lineup matches the majority’s preferred structure (Bob/Frank/Henry/Diana core plus Eve) and best balances trust from the success history with reduced exposure to the two distinct failing configurations.

votes.comment: From my perspective (knowing I’m good), the spies must be split between {Bob, Frank, Charlie} from Mission 3 and {Diana, Eve, Grace, Henry} from Mission 4. This team avoids the most suspicious pool (Charlie/Grace and the double-overlap on me) and matches the broadest non-Frank consensus. Frank’s push to bring back multiple players from the more tainted sets looks riskier than this composition.

Best available compromise: keeps Alice (double-overlap on both fails) and Grace/Charlie (tied to individual fails) off, leans on the only pair from both clean missions (me and Frank), and matches broad table consensus. Any alternative is likely to reintroduce more suspicious overlap.
Two players I suspect least are off this team and the structure fits the consensus core, so I’m fine sending it.

This best matches the broad consensus core and, given I know Frank and Henry are both good (one Merlin, one not), the remaining risk is concentrated in Bob/Eve. Alice being the sole overlap on both failing teams plus Charlie/Grace’s tie-ins to earlier fails make keeping them off more important than avoiding Eve here.
This matches the broadly agreed Bob/Frank/Henry/Diana core while avoiding Alice’s double-fail overlap and the earlier Charlie/Grace associations, with me as the cleanest fifth from the fail patterns.
Team includes both Henry and Eve, which I still don’t trust given the fail on Mission 4 and the safer options from earlier clean teams.

As a known good to myself and off this 5-player team, I know the remaining 7 players contain exactly 4 good and 3 evil, so any 5-player team drawn from them must include at least one spy; I therefore have to reject.
This best fits the consensus core while minimizing overlap with both failing missions; statistically it looks like our cleanest shot.

discussion.content: Given the patterns, I really don’t want Charlie or Grace on the last team—I'd lean toward something like me, Bob, Frank, Henry, and Diana, since that keeps us to at most one person from the last failing lineup.

I really don’t like that Alice is the only overlap between the fail on 3 and the fail on 4, so for the last team I’d strongly prefer something like me, Frank, Henry, Diana, and then just one of Charlie/Grace/Eve (but not Alice).

I’m with Bob that we shouldn’t take Alice, and I also don’t love Grace or me on this last team given the fail histories, so I’d lean toward Bob, Frank, Henry, Diana, and Eve as the cleanest-looking five.
I’m most comfortable locking in Bob, Frank, Henry, and me as the core, and I slightly prefer adding Eve over Alice/Grace/Charlie for the fifth given the fail patterns.

I’m on board with the Bob/Frank/Henry/Diana core and I think adding me makes the most sense, since that keeps Alice (the only double-overlap on both failing missions) off while also avoiding Charlie/Grace who are tied to the other fail.

I’m really not sold on Henry being in this “safe core” when his only appearance was on the failed Mission 4, so I’d rather build around the people from the two clean teams (Bob, me, plus some combo of Alice/Charlie/Grace) and leave both Henry and Eve off this last one.

I really don’t want Alice on this team given she’s the only overlap between both fails, and I’m more inclined to trust Henry over bringing in Eve or Charlie again. I’d back a lineup of Bob, Frank, Henry, Diana, and me.

Given where we are, I think the safest core is Bob/Frank/Diana/me, and between the options for the fifth I still slightly prefer Eve over re-adding Alice (double overlap on both fails) or dipping back into Charlie/Grace.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and stayed consistently on early successful teams, which helped me look trustworthy, but I didn’t convert that trust into stronger pushes against the wrong teams later. I should have pressed harder on the pattern of Bob/Frank/Charlie/Henry being over-represented on critical missions and been more skeptical when Mission 3 failed. As leader on Mission 4, I could have tightened my team selection more aggressively around the most consistently clean players instead of spreading risk.

player_observations.Bob: Bob appeared consistently trustworthy by being on the first two successful missions, which made it easy to clear him mentally and likely made evil comfortable hiding next to him. He didn’t strongly challenge later team compositions, which indirectly let evil shape Missions 3 and 5 without heavy resistance.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie slipped smoothly onto the successful Mission 2 and then onto the failing Mission 3, using that early success to mask his role as Mordred. He played a low-profile, quietly-included style that avoided drawing attention even after the first fail, which was effective at keeping suspicion spread out.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival and the final mission leader, Diana tried to balance information with team selection but ended up including two evil players on Mission 5. Her team choices suggested she was partially misreading Merlin’s signals or over-trusting certain players who had been on mixed-result missions. She played actively and took on responsibility, but her late-game read was just off enough to swing the result.
player_observations.Eve: Eve maintained enough ambiguity to get onto the crucial Mission 4 and then the final Mission 5, contributing to both fails as the Assassin. She didn’t need to be heavily vocal; her value came from blending into mid-trust territory and riding along with more central figures like Diana and Henry. Her positioning on the last mission was especially decisive.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, Frank did an excellent job getting on early clean teams and quietly steering Missions 1 and 2 toward success. However, his later influence wasn’t strong enough to keep multiple evils off Missions 3–5, suggesting he was being careful not to be too obvious and may have erred on the side of subtlety. His play looked consistently good-aligned from my perspective, which means he succeeded at looking trustworthy but not at fully converting that into safe endgame teams.
player_observations.Grace: Grace led Mission 2 and selected a fully good team, which strongly increased her perceived reliability and mine. After that, she stayed relatively low-drama, which kept her away from heavy suspicion but also limited her late impact on steering away from bad teams. Her conservative, solid early pick helped evil later because it gave us a false sense of security in the pool of players that followed.
player_observations.Henry: Henry, as Morgana, successfully embedded himself on key mid- and late-game missions (3, 4, and 5), contributing to the chain of fails while never becoming the clear consensus suspect. His willingness to sit on mixed teams and exploit the confusion around Merlin/percival reads made him look like a reasonable inclusion rather than a glaring risk. He was central to evil’s success by consistently being on pivotal missions without drawing enough heat to be locked out.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Frank and the early Mission 1/2 teams, but I didn’t push hard enough to lock in a tight core of confirmed goods for the later missions. I should have been more suspicious of Charlie after Mission 3 and more vocal against adding both Henry and Eve to the final team.

player_observations.Alice: Led a safe first mission and generally projected a solid good vibe, but didn’t manage to force a consensus around a clearly good pool later in the game. Tended to play a bit cautiously, which made it harder to counter the coordinated evil moves.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very patient evil game by passing Mission 2 to build strong trust, then striking on Mission 3 at a critical moment. Blended in well with the good team and leveraged that early success to stay off the main suspect list for too long.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, Diana tried to steer the endgame but ended up with both Henry and Eve on the final team, suggesting uncertainty about Merlin’s identity. Showed willingness to take responsibility by leading Mission 5, but the team composition was too risky.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was subtle, staying low-impact early (no fails on Missions 1 or 2) and only revealing full aggression on Mission 5 with a double fail. Worked well with Henry to apply just enough pressure on Missions 4 and 5 without drawing clear suspicion earlier.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, Frank did a good job guiding early mission success and staying alive, but his signals weren’t strong or clear enough to prevent evil from getting onto the last mission. His play looked convincingly good without being blatantly directional, which protected him but also left some ambiguity for the rest of us.
player_observations.Grace: Led a clean Mission 2 that helped establish an early trust network, and generally came across as straightforward good. However, wasn’t able to translate that trust into decisive influence over the critical late-game team selections.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, Henry played an excellent deceptive role, staying quiet enough early and then participating in the key failing missions (4 and 5). Managed to get onto the final team despite prior involvement in a fail, indicating strong social positioning and effective misdirection.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar and built trust by passing Mission 2, which helped keep suspicion spread across multiple players later on. I could have been more proactive in subtly steering teams toward including at least one other evil player earlier, rather than relying so much on later mission chaos. Overall, my Mordred value was realized because Merlin never had clean leverage against me, but I can improve at more active narrative shaping.

player_observations.Alice: You played very straightforwardly good and took a big swing on Mission 4 with a wide team, which ended up injecting a lot of ambiguity into who the spy was. Your willingness to include multiple middling-suspicion players made it harder for good to narrow things down.
player_observations.Bob: You gravitated toward familiar, early-trusted players (especially reusing Frank) and tended to anchor on earlier mission results when evaluating later teams. That consistency made you look very village-like but also a bit exploitable, since evil could predict which cores you’d be comfortable with.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, you seemed cautious and hesitant to hard-clear or hard-push anyone, which kept Merlin somewhat protected but also limited your impact on team direction. Your final mission team choice showed you were still spread on suspects, giving evil the opening they needed.
player_observations.Eve: You blended in well on table talk and then timed your mission fails effectively, especially on Missions 4 and 5 where your presence kept good guessing between multiple suspects. As Assassin, you benefited a lot from the confusion around Henry and me, preserving a thick cloud of doubt.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, you clearly had good instincts about some evils but never fully pinned me down, which shows Mordred’s effect was working. Your tendency to stay within socially plausible suspicion ranges (not pushing too hard on specific people) kept you safe but also reduced pressure on the actual spies.
player_observations.Grace: You came across as solidly good and trustworthy, and your Mission 2 leadership with a clean result helped set a baseline of trust for several players. Later, you didn’t strongly dictate direction, which let louder voices carry the final missions in ways that helped evil.
player_observations.Henry: You leaned into the Morgana ambiguity nicely, becoming a natural lightning rod once Mission 4 failed with you on it. Your participation in the double-fail on Mission 5 sealed the game and capitalized on the existing suspicion that had already been building your way.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on suspecting Bob and Frank together after Mission 3’s single fail, which made me discount the possibility that Henry and Charlie were coordinated evil and misread Frank’s subtle Merlin signaling. I need to be more deliberate about tracking who is trying to preserve flexible team options vs. who is aggressively locking in certain narratives, and I should have pushed harder for a safer composition on Mission 5 instead of compromising with multiple unknowns.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly and felt transparently good, but her leadership on Mission 4 ended up mixing too many uncertain players, which obscured information and gave evil room to hide.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently landed on early teams and looked very trustworthy, but his inclusion in almost every critical team made it hard to separate genuine trust from him being unintentionally used as cover for evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well and let others drive the table talk; as Mordred, he avoided being a focal point and benefitted from not being loudly wrong or right, which made him feel like a safe mid-pack pick.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively quiet and avoided sharp stances, which kept suspicion low; as Assassin, she positioned herself well to remain team-viable until the endgame and to have good Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he played very cautiously and didn’t hard-push against specific evils, which protected his identity but also left good without enough strong guidance on the final team.
player_observations.Grace: Felt solidly good, especially around her Mission 2 leadership, but her later support patterns didn’t decisively narrow down the evil candidates, keeping the mid-game foggier than it needed to be.
player_observations.Henry: Did an excellent job as Morgana by mirroring a ‘quietly insightful good’ style—he made just enough reasonable suggestions to appear helpful while subtly steering key missions into dangerous lineups.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated effectively with Charlie and Henry to stack late-game mission fails and maintained a believable good façade through Missions 1 and 2, which helped us avoid early suspicion. I could improve by seeding more nuanced, proactive suspicion on non-Merlin players earlier, to make the final assassination decision feel less obvious and more naturally justified in table talk.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and leaned on consensus, often supporting teams that felt 'safe' rather than driving her own reads, which made her look generically good but not strongly insightful. Her leadership on Mission 4 seemed more about covering bases than pushing a strong theory, which made it easier for evil to slip onto the team.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to trust prior successful teams heavily, which made him slow to revise reads even after Mission 3 failed. His willingness to repeatedly go with similar cores gave evil a comfortable structure to hide in.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, blended into the background well and avoided drawing direct heat, especially after Mission 3’s fail where suspicion could have turned toward him more strongly. He let others drive major arguments, which helped keep his own alignment relatively opaque.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, she showed some protectiveness over certain players but didn’t clearly or forcefully translate that into public Merlin-protection logic. Her Mission 5 team felt like an attempt to balance risk and info but ended up giving evil the window they needed.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he guided team selection subtly rather than loudly, nudging toward safer configurations without over-claiming certainty, which was good discipline. However, his slight pattern of de-prioritizing specific evil players on critical teams gave just enough of a trail for me to identify him as Merlin in the end.
player_observations.Grace: Played straightforwardly good, generally following logical voting patterns and not overcomplicating the read structure. Her Mission 2 leadership was conservative and reasonable, which helped build trust in her but also reassured evil that we could pass early without much scrutiny.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, he took on a more active, opinionated role, which helped muddy the Merlin/percival information dynamic and created plausible alternative ‘wise’ voices. His participation in the failed missions was timed well, maintaining just enough doubt so that he didn’t become the default evil read.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly inferred that Charlie was likely evil after Mission 3 and strongly suspected that the Mission 4 fail came from Eve or Henry, but I didn’t communicate those reads clearly or forcefully enough through my team preferences and voting. I also failed to steer the table away from putting both Eve and Henry on the final mission, which made it easy for evil to double-fail Mission 5. In future games, I should signal my suspicions more decisively through consistent voting patterns and clearer support/opposition to specific team comps.

player_observations.Alice: Tends to build early-game trust with simple, safe comps and seems fairly risk-averse when leading crucial missions, leaning on previously successful team members.
player_observations.Bob: Plays straightforward and cooperative, often accepting teams that look mechanically reasonable and not pushing very hard for their own reads, which makes them appear consistently village-aligned.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, blended in well by passing Mission 2 and then taking the key single fail on Mission 3, showing a preference for subtle, timing-based sabotage rather than constant aggression.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, appeared very engaged in reading the Merlin/Morgana signals but sometimes hesitated on hard stances, suggesting a cautious style that tries not to overcommit without enough information.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, played very patiently, only revealing aggression late by participating in the double fail on Mission 5, and generally maintained a low profile that didn’t draw much suspicion earlier.
player_observations.Grace: Showed a logical, methodical approach to team selection and seemed to prioritize including previously successful members, which helped build trust but may have made them somewhat predictable.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, did a strong job of muddying the Merlin signals by mixing cooperative behavior with well-timed sabotage, especially later in the game when critical missions were on the line.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and stayed generally consistent with a good-aligned voting pattern, especially around Missions 1 and 2, which helped build some early trust. However, I clearly misread the evil core around Charlie/Henry/Eve and was too willing to let strong, confident voices steer the final team, instead of pushing harder to keep at least one of them off critical missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly clean, low-drama good game; her Mission 1 team choice and later leadership on Mission 4 felt sincere, though the single fail there may have unfairly cast some doubt on her judgment.
player_observations.Bob: Appeared reliably pro-mission and was consistently included on early successful teams, which made him look quite trustworthy and possibly like a quiet power good role.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in very well as evil by riding the early successes and then slipping onto Mission 3 with just one fail, creating ambiguity without overexposing himself.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, she projected controlled confidence and tried to anchor late-game decisions, but her final Mission 5 team choice shows she was successfully misled by Morgana/Merlin ambiguity.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively under the radar while still landing on key late missions, and coordinated well enough with other evil roles to help secure Mission 5 with a decisive double fail.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he did a solid job of nudging team compositions in the right direction early while not being obviously loud, but his signaling apparently wasn’t clear enough to pull good away from the Henry/Charlie/Eve axis late game.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very convincing Morgana, projecting just enough insight and confidence to be mistaken for Merlin by Percival and others, which was pivotal in steering the final missions toward evil-heavy teams.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively well-hidden until the later missions, coordinating indirectly with Charlie and Eve to ensure critical mission fails on 3, 4, and 5. I could improve by manipulating team selections earlier so that more suspicion landed on strong good players like Frank and Diana, making the endgame less clear for the good team.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to build teams conservatively around known early successes, which made her teams generally trustworthy but also a bit easier for us to infiltrate once we had a read on her trust circle.
player_observations.Bob: Played as a straightforward, consistent good player—sticking to logical reasoning and prior mission results, which made him look reliably good but also somewhat predictable in team voting.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, stayed disciplined by passing on Mission 2, which preserved his cover and set up a credible fail on Mission 3 when it mattered more.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, clearly tried to protect her Merlin read by centering Frank in later teams, but this also funneled her into picking multiple evils on the final mission under pressure.
player_observations.Eve: Played a bold late-game as Assassin, leaning into risk by failing the final mission alongside me, which decisively secured the evil win and showed comfort operating under heavy suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, did a strong job guiding early success without drawing too much heat, but his influence on team choices later made it clear to us that he was a high-value target and central good voice.
player_observations.Grace: Approached the game methodically, using prior mission results as her main anchor; this made her choices feel reasonable but also made her more easily steered by subtle evil narratives.
